sn24.1:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove.
sn24.1:1.3: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn24.1:1.4: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’”
sn24.1:2.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn24.1:2.2: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn24.1:3.1: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn24.1:3.2: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.1:3.6: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn24.1:3.7: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar.’
sn24.1:3.11: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:3.13: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:3.14: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:4.6: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:4.8: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:4.9: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:4.11: “That which is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by the mind: is that permanent or impermanent?”
sn24.1:4.13: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn24.1:4.15: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn24.1:4.16: ‘Winds don’t blow; rivers don’t flow; pregnant women don’t give birth; the moon and stars neither rise nor set, but stand firm like a pillar’?”
sn24.1:5.1: “When a noble disciple has given up doubt in these six cases, and has given up doubt in suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation,
sn24.1:5.2: they’re called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
